speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: Okay. So we’ll have those corrections made and this will be entered into evidence. Now, you’re a Superintendent with the Ontario Provincial Police?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: MR. FRANK AU

text_clean_combined: That’s correct.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: And how many years have you served with the OPP?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: MR. FRANK AU

text_clean_combined: Twenty-eight (28) years now.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: Did you start your policing career with the OPP?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: MR. FRANK AU

text_clean_combined: I did, yes.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: And back in January when the Freedom Convoy events began, you were a Strategic Commander for the West Region.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: MR. FRANK AU

text_clean_combined: Yes, that’s correct.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: What areas were covered by the West Region?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: MR. FRANK AU

text_clean_combined: West Region is basically Collingwood all the way down to Windsor, all the municipalities in that area that do not have their own police service, is the responsibility of West Region OPP.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: And how many superintendents were there for that region?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: MR. FRANK AU

text_clean_combined: There’s three Superintendents.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: Who are the other two?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: MR. FRANK AU

text_clean_combined: At the time it was Supt. Frankie Campisi, and Supt. Lisa Darling.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: Okay. And do all three of you report to a Chief Superintendent?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: MR. FRANK AU

text_clean_combined: Yes, that’s correct.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: Who was that in January?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: MR. FRANK AU

text_clean_combined: It is C/Supt. Dwight Thib.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: Okay. And as a Superintendent of the West Region, what were your responsibilities back in January of this year?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: MR. FRANK AU

text_clean_combined: As part of my responsibilities, I support four of the 13 detachments that we have in West Region; and, also, I support the Operational Support Inspector, and take on the role of Strategic Commander.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: Okay. And at that time were you based in London?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: MR. FRANK AU

text_clean_combined: That’s correct.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: And I understand that on the 9th of February, you assumed a new role when D/Comm. Harkins appointed you as the Critical Incident Commander in Windsor.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: MR. FRANK AU

text_clean_combined: That’s correct. I received a call from D/Comm. Harkins on the night of February 9th.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: And we heard from D/Chief Crowley yesterday from the Windsor Police Service that you established the joint or unified command with the Windsor Police Service that oversaw all the successful resolution of the blockade in Windsor.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: MR. FRANK AU

text_clean_combined: That’s correct.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: So we’ll come to those events a bit later.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: MR. FRANK AU

text_clean_combined: Okay.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: But I want to start by asking you about your training and experience that qualified you to take on those roles in January and February. Let’s begin with your background with the Incident Command system. What kind of training have you received?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: MR. FRANK AU

text_clean_combined: I have been a crisis negotiator for 13 years of my career, and crisis negotiators are used quite often in incidents, so I had experience that way. I am an Incident Commander as well as of 2012, and then in 2017, I was trained to become a Critical Incident Commander.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: And in terms of the courses that you had to attend before you assumed those roles, tell us about that, too.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: MR. FRANK AU

text_clean_combined: The Critical Incident Commander is a four-week course where you receive training in regards to larger incidents; how to manage them, communication, the execution, the options. You hear several different presentations from your subject matter experts, which include our Emergency Response Team.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: Could I ask you ---
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: COMMISSIONER ROULEAU

text_clean_combined: To slow down?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: --- to go a little slower for the interpreters, please?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: COMMISSIONER ROULEAU

text_clean_combined: Sure. My apologies. Subject matter experts, that would include crisis negotiators, our Emergency Response Team, our Tactical Rescue Unit, our canine units, all options that would be used in a critical incident.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: And which institution offer that course?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: MR. FRANK AU

text_clean_combined: It’s through the OPP.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: And what year did you complete those ---
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: MR. FRANK AU

text_clean_combined: Two thousand and seventeen (2017).
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: Were there different levels of training for an Incident Commander or Critical Incident Commander?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: MR. FRANK AU

text_clean_combined: The Critical Incident Commander with the OPP is somewhat the highest at this point, ---
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: Okay.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: MR. FRANK AU

text_clean_combined: --- as far as the training.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: And I understand you met some colleagues that you worked with ultimately when you were deployed to Windsor in February.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: MR. FRANK AU

text_clean_combined: Yes, that’s correct. I took the Critical Incident Command course with now Interim Chief Jason Bellaire of Windsor Police.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: And now you also took on some leadership training more recently. Tell us about that, too.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: MR. FRANK AU

text_clean_combined: I was fortunate enough to complete the Canadian Police College Executive Leadership in Policing course, which is a year course. And I also finished the Rotman Leadership Course just in the fall of 2021.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: And you met another colleague who was to work in the Windsor Incident Command; right?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: MR. FRANK AU

text_clean_combined: That’s correct.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: Who was that?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: MR. FRANK AU

text_clean_combined: Inspector Karel DeGraaf and I completed the Rotman course together.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: Okay. And isn’t it true that you not only attended those courses and you had experience as an Incident Commander and Critical Incident Commander, you also taught courses in that regard?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: MR. FRANK AU

text_clean_combined: Yes, I have debriefed different calls on the Incident Command course as well as the Critical Incident Command course.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: Now, there are two frameworks that we’ve heard a little about that, as I understand from our interview, kind of guided you when you approached the situation in Windsor. One was the OPP framework for police preparedness for Indigenous Critical Incidents. For those of us who are not familiar with that framework, can you tell us -- give us a quick overview of what that is?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: MR. FRANK AU

text_clean_combined: It stresses the importance of communication and a tiered response, almost like a stepladder that you explore different options amongst -- during the incident to see what option would be best to safely resolve it. An important part of that policy is the fact, as I said, communication and also the introduction of our provincial liaison team. That’s part -- a key part of the framework as well.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: Okay. We’ll come to a little bit more about that. And the other framework is the CACP, or Canadian Association of Chief of Police, national framework. And you mentioned in our interview that that was consistent with the OPP critical policy. Tell us more about that.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: MR. FRANK AU

text_clean_combined: That’s correct. It certainly highlights communication and the different tiered responses depending on the situation.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: So were you familiar with both frameworks when you took on the role of Critical Incident Commander in February?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: MR. FRANK AU

text_clean_combined: Yes.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: All right. Let’s turn now to -- before we get to your role as the Critical Incident Commander in February, I want to start with your role as the Strategic Commander for the West Region in January. So that was when you were still working out of London, Ontario.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: MR. FRANK AU

text_clean_combined: Yes.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: And what -- you talked to us a little bit about your responsibilities as the Strategic Commander, but what, specifically, were your involvement with respect to the Freedom Convoy or the protests travelling through the west?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: MR. FRANK AU

text_clean_combined: We had -- at the time, we had numerous slow rolls and protests happening throughout our different municipalities. I had oversight on the events, worked with the Operational Support Inspector and each Detachment Commander to ensure that we had the proper resources to effectively look after the protests or slow rolls that were going through our municipalities.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: Now, when Commissioner Carrique testified at the hearing, he told us about a blockade on Highway 402 on or around February the 6th. Were you familiar with that incident?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: MR. FRANK AU

text_clean_combined: Yes, I was involved in that incident.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: Tell us about your involvement.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: MR. FRANK AU

text_clean_combined: On February 6th, which was a Sunday, we became aware that the protestors had blocked the bridge, the Blue Water Bridge, in Lampton County. As a result, our Provincial Liaison Team as well as our frontline members were deployed to the area. Our Provincial Liaison Team were able to develop a rapport and a relationship with the protestors and, ultimately, there was a number of different trucks that weren’t able to cross the border at that time, and one of them ultimately was a friend of one of the protestors. And one of the truck drivers -- I believe it was livestock. He had some -- he was travelling with something that needed to be in a certain area by a certain time. PLT liaised with the ruck driver that was stuck and with the protestors and were able to work out the opening of the bridge, so that was a success. The bridge did reopen. We also learned around that time that that group or similar to that group of protestors were planning on doing a slow roll on Highway 402 that week. So we liaised with the organizers of the slow roll and -- to try to find out as much information as possible so that we could have the proper resources in place.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: So first with respect to the incident on the Blue Water Bridge, how long did it take to resolve that event?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: MR. FRANK AU

text_clean_combined: I’d have to make reference to my notes, but I know it was maybe two hours, at most two to three hours.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: So it was really short.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: MR. FRANK AU

text_clean_combined: Yes.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: And was Highway 402 the highway that led to Sarnia, the Blue Water Bridge?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: MR. FRANK AU

text_clean_combined: That’s correct.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: And would that be within the OPP jurisdiction of the police?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: MR. FRANK AU

text_clean_combined: Highway 402 is, correct.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: Okay. Now, you spoke about other slow roll events and we heard a little bit about that yesterday from Deputy Chief Crowley. What other protests or slow rolls were happening in the West Region around that time?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: MR. FRANK AU

text_clean_combined: If memory serves me, we almost had a slow roll in each municipality, but ones that I can recall specifically would be Essex County, Norfolk County, Brant County, South Bruce County, Huron County, so there was quite a few.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: And as the Strategic Commander at that time responsible for these events, what steps did you take to monitor the situation or to prepare for any further escalation of the events?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: MR. FRANK AU

text_clean_combined: Each event was specifically assigned to the Detachment Commander. He or she would then assign an Incident Commander to have oversight of the specific event happening in their area. They would also work with our Provincial Liaison Team to find out as much information from the protestors. And we would ensure, from a regional level, that they had the supports that they needed.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: Now, were you a recipient of the OPP Hendon Reports?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: MR. FRANK AU

text_clean_combined: Yes.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: And did you read them regularly?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: MR. FRANK AU

text_clean_combined: Yes, but I focused on the areas that were involving our municipalities.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: So turning now -- turning our attention now to Windsor, we heard yesterday that there was a Hendon Report on February the 4th that deals specifically with the potential blockade. So I could take you to that report. The document number is OPP00000825. If we go to page 6, please. If we go down -- so you see the second bullet says: “Commercial truck drivers and supporters may conduct slow rolls on roadways near the Ambassador Bridge over the next three days and may attempt to block bridge on February 7.” So this seems to be -- compared to the earlier reports, this seems to be more specific warning particular to the bridge and with a date. Do you remember if you received this report or read it at around that time?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: MR. FRANK AU

text_clean_combined: I don’t recall.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: Okay. And do you know what actions, if any, were taken by the OPP to mitigate that risk?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: MR. FRANK AU

text_clean_combined: I can speak to February 7th. That’s when I became aware through Superintendent Crowley, now Interim Deputy Chief, that the bridge had been blocked. I received an email from him. I then had a conversation with him asking him what he needed, and at that time, he was looking for information in regards to what was available. I said basically whenever you needed ---
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: I think I know the one you’re referring to. Did you say February the 7th?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: MR. FRANK AU

text_clean_combined: Seventh. That’s ---
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: But before we get to that, I think there was another email earlier that you were copied on, so if I could take you to that earlier email?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: MR. FRANK AU

text_clean_combined: Sure.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: I believe it’s dated February the 4th, and the document number is WPS000001880. So for context, I believe this is an email from Chief Superintendent Thib to ---
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: MR. FRANK AU

section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: MR. FRANK AU

text_clean_combined: I learned, obviously, about the numbers, what they were dealing with in regards to attendance, as well as vehicles, the types of vehicles. I also learned the area that they had kind of blocked the length of it, where it is located in the city. I also learned about an arrest that was made. So there was a person who had jumped the curb and into the crowd. That person, obviously, was charged and arrested with dangerous drive.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: M’hm.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: MR. FRANK AU

text_clean_combined: And that the crowd became very agitated when the arrest occurred. And they actually took the opportunity to expand the area that they had been in. I learned too, from Deputy Chief Crowley, that the crowd itself was somewhat disorganized and disjointed, hard to kind of figure out exactly what they wanted, or to communicate or negotiate with them. And at that time as well, he explained that there had been a number of transport trucks and vehicles on the bridge, but they had all been removed at that point. So I made the decision that I asked S/Sgt. Jamie Smith of Essex OPP, so he would be the closest Incident Commander, to attend the Command Post for the evening. I also asked that our situational reports be implemented. So it’s basically a template. We introduced those to the Command Post. speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: If we go back to your summary, I want to take you to page 3, because you spoke to us about this email. And then at the end of that paragraph, ---
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: MR. FRANK AU

text_clean_combined: M’hm.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: --- you said: “Superintendent Earley nonetheless believed that a policing solution to the demonstration was possible…” What did you mean by that? The policing solution, in your mind?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: MR. FRANK AU

text_clean_combined: I still believed and was hopeful that negotiations could occur and that we could develop a rapport and a relationship with the protestors through our Provincial Liaison Teams.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: MR. FRANK AU

text_clean_combined: That’s correct.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: Now, before we go to the next day, earlier that day, before you got the call from Deputy Harkins, I think you told us in the interview that you watched a morning press conference where the Mayor, the Mayor of Windsor, Mayor Dilkens, requested resources without specifying the numbers. Do you remember that?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: MR. FRANK AU

text_clean_combined: Yeah, I don’t remember specifically watching it, but I do know that a request was submitted.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: Right. So -- and during our interview, you shared your perspectives on making public announcements of this nature. Tell us about your view on this.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: MR. FRANK AU

text_clean_combined: In regards to specific numbers requested at incidents?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: No. About making public announcements. I think we’ve heard some evidence that, normally, the requests for resources go from one Chief to another, from Chief to Chief.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: MR. FRANK AU

text_clean_combined: Yes.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: And it’s not typical that public announcements by politicians were made and you shared your perspective on this kind of public announcement, so I’m just hoping that you could enlighten us.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: MR. FRANK AU

text_clean_combined: Okay. It’s been my experience that when any municipal service requires our assistance, no matter what the incident, the request needs to go from their Chief to our Commissioner. The Commissioner’s command team then reviews the request and deploys the requested resources. So to hear it come from a politician was different from my experience.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: And after you became the Critical Incident Commander, did you take any steps to change the approach or any kind of media strategy that you adopted?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: MR. FRANK AU

text_clean_combined: I respect the fact that any Council or Mayor, they can have their own press conferences and release information, but I urged Windsor Police Service to work with the Mayor’s office to make sure that our messages are consistent.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: And was any further public announcements made for resources after you assumed the role of Critical Incident Commander?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: MR. FRANK AU

text_clean_combined: Not that I’m aware of.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: Now, in this case the announcement on the 9th did not specify a particular number, how many officers were needed. Do you have any view on whether those numbers should be made publicly in a request?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: MR. FRANK AU

text_clean_combined: In my opinion, I do not believe that they should be made publicly.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: Why not?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: MR. FRANK AU

text_clean_combined: It jeopardizes perhaps the public and police officer safety. By letting the public know the amount of officers that are attending may lead to people then bolstering their protests or whatever that looks like if they know the tactics or perhaps the amount of officers that are attending an incident.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: Okay. So let’s go now to the next day, February 10th. I understand that you had an early morning call with Deputy Harkins, right ---

speaker: MR. FRANK AU

speaker: MR. FRANK AU

speaker: MR. FRANK AU

speaker: MR. FRANK AU

section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: MR. FRANK AU

speaker: MR. FRANK AU

section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: MR. FRANK AU

section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU

speaker: MR. FRANK AU

text_clean_combined: Correct.

speaker: MR. FRANK AU

section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: MR. FRANK AU

section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: MR. FRANK AU

section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: Now, during the interview, you spoke to us about the importance for the strategic leadership to give the Operational Commanders autonomy.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: MR. FRANK AU

text_clean_combined: Yes.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: Tell us more about that.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: MR. FRANK AU

text_clean_combined: Yes. The autonomy that is required is very important because decisions need to be made in a very timely manner when dealing with critical incidents. So that’s -- really highlights the importance. They also know and can trust in the -- not only the experience the team has but the training, and the subject matter experts, the skillset that they bring. So they know that those decisions being made are the best options for the situation and what’s happening.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: Help us understand why is autonomy connected to timeliness of decision-making?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: MR. FRANK AU

text_clean_combined: You need to make sure that a decision is made. The failure to make a decision can almost be just as bad as making an improper decision. So that’s why the timeliness is very important, right? And these situations, things are happening minute by minute. You need to be able to make decisions based on your awareness. And the CIC has the best situational awareness to make those decisions.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: Why was it the CIC who had the best situational awareness?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: MR. FRANK AU

text_clean_combined: You are in the midst of it. You have all the intel coming in; you are there. You have all the feedback from your subject matter experts, so that’s why you have the utmost situational awareness.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: During your time in Windsor as the Critical Incident Commander, did you enjoy the kind of autonomy that you expected from this strategic leadership?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: MR. FRANK AU

text_clean_combined: I did, and I appreciated it.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU

section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: MR. FRANK AU

section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: MR. FRANK AU

text_clean_combined: No.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU

I was very grateful for the rapport and the relationship that PLT was able to develop with him, and through that, we asked for time or his patience.

speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: We've also heard yesterday about the presence of children ---
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: MR. FRANK AU

text_clean_combined: Yes.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: --- during the blockade. And how did intelligence inform your planning about this aspect?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: MR. FRANK AU

text_clean_combined: I would say that was a concern of mine that if we had to use the plan of action that I wanted the lowest amount of children to be there. Intelligence was able to provide me with areas that they had detected where the children were hanging out or were present in the protest. They were also able to tell me that, because of their intelligence, because of their overwatch, that the majority of the children went home at night, and very little of them stayed overnight. And so that led me to, obviously, looking at the option of going first thing in the morning with any plan of operation if needed.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: Was that the plan to have the action begin early in the morning?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: MR. FRANK AU

text_clean_combined: Yes.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: And what considerations led you to that decision?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: MR. FRANK AU

text_clean_combined: Knowing from intel that they had not observed any children overnight and that when children were present, it was usually not until later in the day.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: What about the size of the crowd?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: MR. FRANK AU

text_clean_combined: Absolutely. So the -- and certain times of night, so the crowd, as in my summary and I know Deputy Chief Crowley spoke to it, it would get more unruly at certain times of night, and so we had to consider that and numbers were higher at certain times of night. But as it got colder and the later it got in the evening, a lot of people did return home. So by considering an early morning operation, that again would decrease, hopefully decrease the number of protesters that we were dealing with.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: Turning our attention now to the overall plan. If we go to your summary at page 6, and we go down, that's right, to the section "Approval of Plans", the second paragraph. So, "On February [the] 11[th], Superintendent Earley also approved an overall operational plan titled "Operations Plan: Freedom Convoy, Windsor Ambassador Bridge." The plan stated that it contemplated "an escalation in police response that is a considered and measured approach," and that "[e]vents associated with Ambassador Bridge blockade/convoys shall be addressed at the lowest competent level in an effort to affect a peaceful resolution." " So earlier, you mentioned in the context of discussing the frameworks, I think you talked about the measured approach, the use of PLT to engage and all of that. I want to ask you specifically to explain about this concept of addressing events at the lowest competent level in the context of a kind of ladder or escalation. What does that mean, the lowest competent level?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: MR. FRANK AU

text_clean_combined: The less invasive, the less - - so lowest competent level would be -- the prime example would be our Provincial Liaison Team, you know, being able to discuss the removal or -- of protesters. For them to leave on their own would be ideal.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: So that's what you would try first?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: MR. FRANK AU

text_clean_combined: Absolutely.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: And then if that did not meet with success, then you escalate?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: MR. FRANK AU

text_clean_combined: Yes.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: What would be the next ladder or the next step up the ladder?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: MR. FRANK AU

text_clean_combined: I think jointly along with PLT, we are also using a media strategy to make sure that we were educating everybody in regards to that it was unlawful to be there, that there was other options that they could express freedom of speech. So there was the media attached at the same time as Provincial Liaison Teams were trying to develop rapport with the protestors.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: And then if that didn’t work?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: MR. FRANK AU

text_clean_combined: So next steps, we looked for different options in regards to enforcement. I do know that I had conversations with Windsor about their bylaws. There was a number of different parking bylaws in that area. So we learned that the protestors would park on side streets and then attend the protests. Their parking on side streets were illegal. So their bylaw enforcement was then deployed to the area. So a number of different tickets were given out to the vehicles, as well as some were towed. So that’s just another level to let protestors know that they aren’t to be there.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: What’s next step up?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: MR. FRANK AU

text_clean_combined: So again, all of these steps are not independent. All of these things are continuing. So even as cars are being towed by bylaw, we’re still trying to have negotiations and develop rapport with the protestors through PLT, we’re still using media to get that message out. The next step would be enforcement.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: So we heard yesterday that even during the enforcement phase, attempts were still being made to allow some protestors to continue to protest, perhaps on the sidewalk outside the exclusion zone. Can you tell us more about that?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: MR. FRANK AU

text_clean_combined: So the set area, or the operational area, was certainly explained through our social -- our media strategy, through the PLT, that people needed to remove -- be removed from there, or remove themselves. And then other options throughout the city are really available. Any public area. We have to keep in mind though that there are private businesses as well, and they wouldn’t welcome protestors. So we had to make sure that we educated them in regards to that.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: That’s remarkably quick. Within hours.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: MR. FRANK AU

text_clean_combined: Yes.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: What happened during those hours?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: MR. FRANK AU

text_clean_combined: Quite a bit of back and forth in regards to just clarity as to what Mr. Neufeld was asking. And then, of course, it was the Commissioner’s command team who assisted in getting the letter so quickly, but it certainly demonstrated that we were trying our best to, you know, to get the protestors what they were asking for.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: You were still optimistic about the lowest competent level?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: MR. FRANK AU

text_clean_combined: Yes. Yes, I was.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: Okay. So at 5:30, you engaged -- you took part in a teleconference ---
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: MR. FRANK AU

text_clean_combined: Yes.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: --- with some of the strategic leadership and you learned that -- so if we go down further the page. So near the middle of that paragraph, starting “At 5:30…”, do you see the reference to: “Superintendent Alakas informed call participants that PLT would be providing a letter to the Ottawa protestors that was similar to the letter from the provincial government to the Windsor protestors…” Right?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: MR. FRANK AU

text_clean_combined: Correct.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: So now Superintendent -- Acting Superintendent Beaudin has testified at this hearing a week or so earlier.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: MR. FRANK AU

text_clean_combined: Yes.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: And he told us -- perhaps the best way to summarize his evidence is if I take you to his summary.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: MR. FRANK AU

text_clean_combined: Okay.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: Can we go to WTS00000037, please? So this is the interview summary of Insp. Beaudin.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: MR. FRANK AU

text_clean_combined: Okay.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: If we go to page 4? Go down. So you’ll see that on February the 11th, the same day you were dealing with this break through in Windsor: “On February 11[th], 2022, Inspector Beaudin met virtually with Mr. Stewart and Mr. Hutchinson again. The plan at that point was to offer a meeting in exchange for demonstration leaders demanding that the trucks exit downtown Ottawa and denounce any criminal activity. Inspector Beaudin then briefed Acting Deputy Chief Ferguson, who was in agreement with the plan. Later that day, Inspector Beaudin also exchanged emails with OPP Superintendent Alakas about the actions being taken in Windsor and what kind of reaction that might create among the demonstrators in Ottawa.” So things were happening in Ottawa and you were dealing with rapidly developing situations in Windsor.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: MR. FRANK AU

text_clean_combined: Yes.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: So going back to your summary, this call at 5:30, when you were informed by Alakas, Supt. Alakas about this development in Ottawa. Remember the middle of the paragraph?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: MR. FRANK AU

text_clean_combined: Yes.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: So what -- the evidence given by Insp. Beaudin, does that accord with your understanding on the 11th at around 5:30?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: MR. FRANK AU

text_clean_combined: Yes.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: And then if we go down the page, a serious of meetings continuing to about if we go to the next page, continuing to about 7:06 p.m., a series of meetings between you and your command team, as well as between you and your strategic leadership ---
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: MR. FRANK AU

text_clean_combined: Yes.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: --- at the OPP took place. Can you take us through those series of meetings?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: MR. FRANK AU

text_clean_combined: Yes. After the call at approximately 5:30 that included Supt. Alakas, I made the decision that perhaps we need to delay what was happening in Windsor, because of the influence it could have in Ottawa. I then had conversations with the strategic commanders, Deputy Commissioner Harkins and Commissioner Carrique, and learned -- well, they reminded me that I did not need to act in my strategic commander role, that I needed to focus on Windsor. And it was during that conversation that they said, “Are you ready to go? Is your plan ready? Do you have the resources? Will, you know, the plan itself emphasized public and officer safety?” I said yes to that, and then I changed my mind and decided to continue with my plan, realizing that I didn’t know the intimate knowledge of what was going on in Ottawa, because my focus had to be Windsor.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: Right. So going back to your initial concern when you were reconsidering implementing the plan the next day, what implications did you think the action in Windsor may have in Ottawa? What were those concerns?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: MR. FRANK AU

text_clean_combined: That it might agitate things there. And at the same time, I had to -- again, my focus had to be on Windsor. So if we didn’t go forward with the plan and prolonged allowing the protestors to continue, what would that mean for Windsor? And that was my priority.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: And then after you spoke to your command team, you had discussions with the strategic leadership, and that included Commissioner Carrique; right?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: MR. FRANK AU

text_clean_combined: Correct.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: And Deputy Commissioner Harkins?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: MR. FRANK AU

text_clean_combined: Yes.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: And in that discussion, that discussion between the strategic leadership and your role as an operational commander, ---
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: MR. FRANK AU

text_clean_combined: M’hm.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: --- help us understand what was the strategic input and how that effected your decision, ultimately, as the operation commander?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: MR. FRANK AU

text_clean_combined: M’hm. It was a reminder that I did not have all -- good situational awareness of what was happening in Ottawa. They did. And that my focus needed to be on Windsor. And I could them, without a doubt, that the plan was ready, the officers were ready, we had enough resources, we had tried the stepped approach and we were not getting anywhere. Of course, I was hopeful about the letter because at this time it had not been delivered yet, but any CIC will tell you that you have your planning and your resources ready, one of the best options would be not to deploy it because protesters left on their own. So I was still hopeful because the letter hadn't been delivered yet.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: Right. So by 7:06 p.m., what was your final decision?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: MR. FRANK AU

text_clean_combined: That we would be -- if needed, if the letter was not successful, that we would be launching the next morning our Operational Plan.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: Now, this is the paragraph that you made the correction when we began ---
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: MR. FRANK AU

text_clean_combined: Correct.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: --- today's examination, and the correction you made was to the effect that it was your decision ---
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: MR. FRANK AU

text_clean_combined: Yes.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: --- as opposed to a decision made by the strategic leadership.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: MR. FRANK AU

text_clean_combined: Correct.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: Why is that important to you?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: MR. FRANK AU

text_clean_combined: Because all of those decisions moving forward in regards to Windsor and the plan, they were all my decisions.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: Okay. So after this decision was made, at 8:00 p.m., if we go down the page, at 8:00 p.m., the letter that was previously approved was now signed by ---
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: MR. FRANK AU

text_clean_combined: M'hm.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: --- Minister Jones and it was distributed to the protesters. What effect, if any, did it have that distribution of the letter?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: MR. FRANK AU

text_clean_combined: Very little. Very little. It was disappointing.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: And ---
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: MR. FRANK AU

text_clean_combined: Very little.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: And tell us about the -- what was going on by then with the protesters?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: MR. FRANK AU

text_clean_combined: Well, because of the time of day, we had seen this throughout the week, that was kind of the heavier times for numbers of people. Some sort -- somewhat I would describe as a party atmosphere was happening, from usually eight o'clock on during the evenings, and this was no different. So the party atmosphere had certainly began, and again, it was just very disappointing that the letter had little effect ---
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: It wasn't ---
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: MR. FRANK AU

text_clean_combined: --- although I appreciated all the efforts getting the letter.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: That wasn't what you were hoping for.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: MR. FRANK AU

text_clean_combined: No.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: So now was it time to escalate up the ladder?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: MR. FRANK AU

text_clean_combined: Yes.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: Okay. So that takes us to the end of the day on the 11th. My colleague --- Mr. Commissioner, my colleague, Ms. Hedaraly, will continue examination with the events the following day.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. FRANK AU
speaker: MR. FRANK AU

text_clean_combined: Okay, thank you. Is this a good time for the morning break and we can come back at -- in 15 minutes?

text_clean_combined: --- EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY:
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY
speaker: NA

text_clean_combined: Good morning, Superintendent Earley.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY
speaker: MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY

text_clean_combined: Morning.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: My name is Sajeda Hedaraly. I'm Commission Counsel, and I will be asking you some questions this morning.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY
speaker: MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY

text_clean_combined: Okay, thank you.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: I'm going to continue where my colleague left off on February 11th. A lot of things happened that day. On that day, the Ontario Supreme Court of Justice also granted an injunction prohibiting a blockade on the Ambassador Bridge. Can you explain briefly how you used this injunction and if you found it helpful in terms of the blockade?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY
speaker: MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY

text_clean_combined: The injunction was another tool that could be considered by myself and my team. We also made sure that the injunction was included in the media strategy so that everyone was aware that it existed. And -- so that's how it was used. I saw it as a tool.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: I'd like to pull up your notes, please, at OPP00004551. If we go down to page 9, there is a note at 4:58 p.m. that says: "[P]rotesters are getting ready to leave now that injunction stands - intel from crowd." What was the source of this Intelligence?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY
speaker: MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY

text_clean_combined: That was coming from some of the officers from the frontline, as well as perhaps the -- and I can't recall exactly, but it was being discussed amongst the crowd.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: And so it says that protesters are getting to leave. Did some leave because of the injunction?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY
speaker: MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY

text_clean_combined: Very little, if any at all. I can't recall.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: On February 11th there was also a province-wide emergency declared by Premier Ford under the Emergency Management and Civil Protection Act. How did that impact the blockade?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY
speaker: MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY

text_clean_combined: Again, we used it as part of our media strategy. We made sure that people were aware that -- what it meant to them if you were protesting. We actually did up information pamphlets for the crowd that explained some of the consequences of the Act and had Provincial Liaison Teams distribute those. But again, some did leave as a result. Others did not.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: Did you find that one of these two tools, the emergency measures or the injunction, was more or less useful than the other, did they work in conjunction? Can you just explain a little more?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY
speaker: MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY

text_clean_combined: I would say they worked in conjunction and, as I’ve mentioned several times, the situation being so dynamic that a lot of options are useful, and so I saw both of them as tools, as options for us.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: Great. So we talked a little bit earlier about resources that were necessary for the plan to be implemented on the 12th.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY
speaker: MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY

text_clean_combined: Yes.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: One of the things that the plan required is towing capacity.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY
speaker: MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY

text_clean_combined: Yes.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: Correct? So where did you obtain tow trucks?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY
speaker: MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY

text_clean_combined: So towing was included in our traffic plan and knowing that we may have to have an operation - - an action of operation and remove vehicles, that obviously had to be considered. Windsor Police Service has a contract with a local towing company who made their tow trucks available, and also, because we weren’t sure the exact numbers of what would need to be towed, we had the option of tow trucks come in from Detroit.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: So first for the local company that Windsor Police Service had a contract with, was there any issues with their willingness to assist in the context of the protests?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY
speaker: MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY

text_clean_combined: No, there was not.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: And as for the tow trucks that came from Detroit, I’d like to pull up WPS000001090, please. This is an email from Chief Minuzo (sic) to Deputy Chief Bellaire that forwards an email from the Michigan government. In there, we see that the -- that Michigan doesn’t have state resources to offer but are willing to put the Windsor Police Service in touch with private contractors. And as you can see, Chief Minuzo (sic) says they have no machinery or tow trucks to offer. “Please let the team know there is no assistance in tow trucks or machinery from the U.S.”. Were you made aware of the fact that the States didn’t have tow trucks to offer?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY
speaker: MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY

text_clean_combined: Not that specific detail, but I do know that the Inspector in charge of the traffic and towing plan had made connections with perhaps the contractors that they mentioned to arrange for tow trucks to be on standby.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: And when did you obtain the tow trucks from Michigan?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY
speaker: MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY

text_clean_combined: They came -- I believe they came the morning of the 12th.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: And I understand that they weren’t used in the end?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY
speaker: MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY

text_clean_combined: Correct.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: When did they leave?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY
speaker: MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY

text_clean_combined: That day.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: I understand that the blockade was only cleared on the following day?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY
speaker: MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY

text_clean_combined: That’s correct.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: Why were the trucks sent back to the U.S. if the blockade wasn’t cleared yet?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY
speaker: MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY

text_clean_combined: The area that we were able to clear on the 12th was significant, was more than we anticipated, and so the area that we needed to continue to clear on the 13th did not have a large amount of vehicles, so we were confident that the tow company from Windsor would be able to support what we needed.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: As for the resources that were required, I understand that you also arranged for road barriers to hold areas that were cleared?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY
speaker: MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY

text_clean_combined: That’s correct.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: What did you get to use as road barriers, what kind of resources?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY
speaker: MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY

text_clean_combined: Windsor Police were able to use their -- obviously the connections with the city to use large trucks and as well they had a certain amount of cement barriers that were available to them and then we worked through our partnership with MTO to work with one of their contractors to bring in more cement barriers.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: Were there any issues in securing any of these resources?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY
speaker: MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY

text_clean_combined: No.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: So we also talked earlier about the officers that you needed to carry out the plans. I understand there were frontline officers, POUs, et cetera. I understand that you also had RCMP POU officers?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY
speaker: MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY

text_clean_combined: Correct.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: Do you know how many RCMP officers were deployed in Windsor?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY
speaker: MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY

text_clean_combined: I’d have to refer to my notes, but I believe it was a POU team consisting of approximately 40 and then an additional -- they send their Emergency Response Teams with their POU, so I think there was an additional 10 there. And then we also had assistance from the RCMP officers that assisted on the front line as well.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: Do you know where the RCMP officers came from?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY
speaker: MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY

text_clean_combined: No. I did meet some of them and they were from all over, really.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: I’d like to pull up DOJ.IR.60, rows 11, please, at page 55. At point 250, if we scroll down a little bit, there’s a note that on February 10th, the Windsor Police Service contacted the Minister of Public Safety to request RCMP assistance with respect to the Ambassador Bridge.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY
speaker: MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY

speaker: COMMISSIONER ROULEAU
