section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY
speaker: MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY

text_clean_combined: I’m not sure. I couldn’t comment on that.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: We can pull that down, Mr. Clerk. Thank you. I understand that OPP also deployed PLT ---
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY
speaker: MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY

text_clean_combined: Correct.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: --- members to Windsor? One of the recommendations that you made in your witness summary is that there should be a PLT unit in the Windsor Police Service and PLT training should be provided to Windsor Police officers. Could you please expand on why you made that recommendation?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY
speaker: MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY

text_clean_combined: The efforts and the achievements of our Provincial Liaison Team not only in Windsor, but any incident that they attend, is remarkable, the community as well as our organization. We have a responsibility to try to develop that rapport in incidents where we don’t see eye to eye just so that everybody can be heard. And the Provincial Liaison Team allows that to happen within our different groups within our societies and our communities, and so that’s why I would urge that any police service have some sort of team that allows for that rapport and that communication piece.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: Would you make a similar recommendation regarding POU training that all municipal forces, perhaps, should have that sort of training?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY
speaker: MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY

text_clean_combined: I think depending on where the municipal service is and any key infrastructures that may be targeted, that has to be a consideration. And if, in fact, they can’t have a team, perhaps they need to have some sort of Memorandum of Understanding with another service that could facilitate a POU unit for them if needed.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: So you mentioned earlier today to my colleague that by the end of February 11 you had all the resources that you needed ---
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY
speaker: MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY

text_clean_combined: Correct.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: --- for your plan, and that you implemented it on the morning of February 12th. I understand that one of the reasons that it started early in the morning is that there would be fewer protestors and that no children were likely to be present according to intelligence.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY
speaker: MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY

text_clean_combined: Correct.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: Did you have a contingency plan in place in case there were, indeed, children present?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY
speaker: MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY

text_clean_combined: Yes, we did. So we had a vehicle set aside that would transport children from the scene. We also worked with the local Children’s Aid Society for assistance and, as well, Windsor had kind of spearheaded this but they had their victim response unit in attendance to support any children that may be present.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: And so while we’re on the contingency plan, can you explain the importance of having those kinds of plans in place and how you decide what to prepare for as contingencies?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY
speaker: MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY

text_clean_combined: So as I’ve discussed before, you need to have as many options as possible, especially in an incident like this, and so once you learn of -- or once you have developed that situational awareness and some of the challenges that you may be faced with, but during the incident, you need to make sure that options are covered for each one. So for example, you mention traffic. Well that includes towing as well. And so did the POU plan. Knowing that children were present at different times during the day during this protest, that was an obvious thing for me to make sure that it was addressed.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: So on the morning of February 12th, you start implementing the plan.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY
speaker: MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY

text_clean_combined: Correct.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: Please explain how the plan was carried out?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY
speaker: MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY

text_clean_combined: We had a very early morning briefing, which included every team member that was going to be involved. So that would be all of our POU contingent, as well as the front-line officers, as well as the admin support. The plan was explained to everyone. I addressed everyone and thanked them for their support and efforts. It was shortly after that that we then staged at the areas that were set out in the plan. Before the plan was to move forward, PLT was to, again, address the crowd and let them know that with POU standing behind them, let them know that POU would be attempting to clear the area and giving them another opportunity to leave the area on their own. Another important part of the plan is that we always left an area open so that if somebody wanted to leave the operational area while POU was present, they could do so on their own.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: I’d like to pull up COMM00000926, please, Mr. Clerk. This is a map of Windsor and will maybe help explain the planning by phases that you briefly alluded to earlier.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY
speaker: MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY

text_clean_combined: Okay.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: Or explain more visually how it happened.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY
speaker: MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY

text_clean_combined: Yes.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: So you explained earlier today that the plan was to clear the protestors in phases ---
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY
speaker: MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY

text_clean_combined: M’hm.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: --- because the area was perhaps too large to do it all at once.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY
speaker: MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY

text_clean_combined: Yes.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: Can you explain a little further what the phases were and how they were carried out?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY
speaker: MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY

text_clean_combined: M’hm. It’s a bit difficult to see the side roads. Okay. So right in behind the McDonald’s is obviously where the bridge is. So we wanted to go from the bridge to the intersection, to the train tracks. So there’s train tracks right in front of the entrance to the bridge. That was a certain area. We then wanted to move from the tracks itself to the intersection at the McDonald’s there since that’s a clear point. That would be another section. And then ultimately make our way down to Tecumseh Road. So it was basically put into three different sections. Those were determined by the POU plan and the POU team leaders in regards to what would be most effective. And obviously I respected and trusted their subject matter expertise.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: And I understand that after each area was cleared, you would use the resources that we discussed earlier to block passage?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY
speaker: MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY

text_clean_combined: Correct. So we would use a mixture of the larger trucks, the cement barriers, and officers as well.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: Then once the whole area was cleared after the three phases were completed, that brought us to February 13th?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY
speaker: MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY

text_clean_combined: Yes.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: And that’s when the traffic plan came into place? Is that right?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY
speaker: MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY

text_clean_combined: Correct.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: Can you explain a little bit more what the traffic plan in itself entailed?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY
speaker: MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY

text_clean_combined: Yes. So the traffic plan was to -- as I said to my team that day, it’s one thing to open the bridge, it’s another thing to keep it open. So the traffic plan, the traffic and towing plan addressed maintaining the safe flow of traffic to and from the United States. So the traffic plan incorporated the cement barriers that we discussed, and blocking all the intersections, And I won’t say all, but most of the intersections down Huron Church, to ensure that we did not have protestors coming from the side streets onto the road again and taking it back. The infrastructure of Windsor is a huge challenge when it comes to the entrance of the bridge, and that’s why the need for all the resources that were required in regards to the cement barriers. This traffic plan also had marked areas that intersections were attended by officers, rather than cement barriers, for safety reasons for EMS and fire, to make sure that they could get through, and then also too, we incorporated two different areas for pedestrian traffic as well.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: Were local residents able to cross Huron Church at any point with their personal vehicles?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY
speaker: MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY

text_clean_combined: Yes -- no, they weren’t at certain times, but towards the end, towards E.C. Row and that area, they were able to cross into the other side of the city. Again, another big part of the traffic plan was the media strategy. So we made sure that we communicated this to the community at every step of the way. What it looked like, what the alternate routes were to the different businesses, to the different areas of the city. We made sure that all of those were set up as well. And Windsor Police had, obviously, a big hand in that, working with the Roads Department.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: This is, I think, what Deputy Chief Crowley yesterday referred to as an area of control?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY
speaker: MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY

text_clean_combined: Yes.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: And I think you referred to it in your interview as an exclusion zone?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY
speaker: MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY

text_clean_combined: Yes.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: Under which authority did you create the exclusion zone?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY
speaker: MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY

text_clean_combined: We relied on the Criminal Code for keeping people out of the area. We had specific tasks for the officers that were assigned to the traffic plan to investigate anybody who maybe appeared suspicious, or who may stop in the exclusion zone. So it was clearly communicated to the community through MTO signs, through social media that if you were going to be on Huron Church, you’re going to the bridge.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: And I understand that there were RCMP frontline resources that ---
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY
speaker: MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY

text_clean_combined: Yes.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: --- arrived, as you mentioned little earlier.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY
speaker: MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY

text_clean_combined: Yes.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: And I also understand that there was a delay in swearing them in? Is that right?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY
speaker: MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY

text_clean_combined: Yes, if it ever happened at all. I don’t think it did happen.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: And why was it necessary to swear in these officers, or would it have been useful?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY
speaker: MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY

text_clean_combined: They would be able to address anything under the Criminal Code, but anything under provincial or municipal legislation, they would not be able to address. And since they were being deployed to assist the frontline, we needed them to make -- we needed them to have those options. So what we did instead, because of the delay, is that we made sure that they were partnered with another police service, so OPP or Windsor, that did have those abilities.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: And it’s one of the recommendations that you also made in your interview, that the process for granting RCMP officers provincial and municipal authorities be streamlined.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY
speaker: MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY

text_clean_combined: Yes.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: What was the difficulty in getting them sworn in?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY
speaker: MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY

text_clean_combined: I don’t think there was really clear direction as to who had to do it, when did it have to be done, could it be done remotely, did it have to be done with them in person? So there was a lot of phone calls back and forth with myself, along with Windsor Police Service, at a time where really we should have just been left alone to focus on the incident itself. So that’s what I mean by more streamlined before RCMP officers arrived to assist.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: And did it cause any delay that you had to change your plan to pair RCMP officers with OPP or Windsor Police Service officers?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY
speaker: MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY

text_clean_combined: No, we just looked for a different option, because obviously we needed them on the frontline. So that’s what we did instead.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: So if we go to the next day, on February 14th, the Emergencies Act was invoked by the Federal Government.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY
speaker: MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY

text_clean_combined: Yes.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: In your view, did it have any impact on the situation in Windsor?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY
speaker: MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY

text_clean_combined: Well, things were much different then because the traffic was flowing and it’s hard to say if it had any difference. But I do know that, again, it was communicated through our media strategy that people were aware of the additional Act being legislated and what it meant to them, and the definition of certain things, obviously a bridge that fell under the Act.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: Yesterday Deputy Chief Crowley mentioned that it may have been dissuasive to the protestors ---
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY
speaker: MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY

text_clean_combined: To return.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: --- to come back. Would you agree?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY
speaker: MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY

text_clean_combined: I agree. M’hm. Again, it was another tool that we were able to use.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: Was there a clear plan that you were aware of that the protestors wanted to re-blockade the Ambassador Bridge after it was cleared on the 12th and the 13th?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY
speaker: MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY

text_clean_combined: Yes, we continued to observe and receive intelligence that indicated, I think it was on the date of -- I know it’s in my notes, on the date of the 15th or 16th, there was a Facebook posting that was called Take Back the Bridge, and it was associated to all the things that had -- were then transpiring in Ottawa, and basically the posts were saying, you know, "everybody's -- all the police are gone to Ottawa, so let's take back the bridge." That's something that we watched very closely. Also, Windsor Police had had a group of protesters on a regular basis, and I think Deputy Chief Crowley spoke to that, that would meeting during the convoys on a regular basis. So we maintained kind of Intelligence on, you know, what will that group bring. But certainly there was the fear that they would think that numbers were being deployed to Ottawa and then try to take advantage of that and take back the bridge.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: I think your notes, and I can put them up if that would be helpful, also mention that once the injunction is expired they are looking to blockade again.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY
speaker: MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY

text_clean_combined: Yes.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: Was that also a consideration that the injunction was going to expire?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY
speaker: MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY

text_clean_combined: Yes. There was Intelligence that indicated that, that that's what they were considering.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: So did you think that the renewal of the injunction on February 18th was helpful in preventing that?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY
speaker: MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY

text_clean_combined: Well, to those who, yeah, were going to try to take it back after it expired, yes.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: So as of February 20th, I understand that you adopted a Demobilisation Plan?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY
speaker: MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY

text_clean_combined: Correct.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: What is a Demobilisation Plan?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY
speaker: MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY

text_clean_combined: It was a plan to obviously demobilise our resources, not only for officers but just kind of give the incident entirely to Windsor Police Service as soon as they could kind of sustain it themselves. Also, keeping in mind and respecting the fact of that they had calls for service, they had a city to police as well, so we did it in a staged approach. It also included demobilising certain areas of the Traffic Plan. So on a daily basis, sometimes on a, you know, an hourly basis, we would monitor the traffic flow, along with the Intelligence, along with the reports from our Provincial Liaison Team, and what the frontline was seeing, to see if there was areas where we could perhaps remove some of the barriers. So we evaluated that constantly and opened intersections a point at a time. You can see in the Demobilisation Plan that we actually had some dates set out for each intersection to be considered. Some of those dates were met, other dates were actually opened intersections earlier than we anticipated.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: Maybe for the record we could put it up. It's WPS000000719. I believe at page 4. Perhaps scroll down a little bit. Is this what you were referring to?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY
speaker: MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY

text_clean_combined: That's correct.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: So I see that the latest potential reopening date is March 13th?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY
speaker: MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY

text_clean_combined: Yes.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: Why would it take about three weeks to clear all the intersections?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY
speaker: MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY

text_clean_combined: We -- that was sort of kind of a review of -- based on the information we had when the plan was created. Those two -- the last two intersections were the heavier intersections in regards to protests, and those are the two that are obviously closest to the bridge entrance, so that's why they were kind of put until the end to see how the community as well as the intel and all of that what we were receiving to see how the other intersections were being cleared. Was it being received well? Did we have any other threat of a protest? So that's why it was kind of spanned along that amount of time.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: Do you know when they were ultimately reopened, the last intersection?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY
speaker: MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY

text_clean_combined: I don't. Sorry.

speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: I understand you stopped being Critical Incident Commander in Windsor on February 23rd?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY
speaker: MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY

speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: How was the transition of command from yourself to the Windsor Police Service?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY
speaker: MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY

text_clean_combined: Again, it was seamless. And we worked every day, every night side by side, so really, it was seamless when we left. We just wanted to make sure that Windsor had the proper amount of resources to be able to deal with anything if it should occur. And of course some of our officers remained there until the end of the month, end of February.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: I'd like to take you back to another of your recommendations before we end. You mentioned that the Critical Incident Commander should visit frontline officers and ask them what they need.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY
speaker: MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY

text_clean_combined: M'hm.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: I understand that that's something that you did ---
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY
speaker: MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY

text_clean_combined: I did, yes.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: --- in Windsor?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY
speaker: MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY

text_clean_combined: Yes.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: Is this uncommon?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY
speaker: MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY

text_clean_combined: I think that every Critical Incident Commander attempts to go on ground, it's just because of, again, the dynamic situation, it's not always to do. So once I had an opportunity I did make a point of visiting the different checkpoints to check on the wellness of our members, and when I say "our members" I mean any police officer that was out there. I also asked them for their input, if there was anything else that we needed to get done or that we could do better. It was from one of those visits that the interactive posts in regards to the Traffic Plan and updating on a regular basis it came from a frontline officer, saying, you know, "I'm dealing with a local resident who wasn't sure where the crosswalks were. So could we post it and keep it up-to-date?" So I took that right back to the Command Post and made sure that that was done right away so that a member of the public at any time just could click on a link and know where the cross the road. So it's those things as well. And most importantly, it's a way to thank them for their efforts, considering that a lot of them had been away from home for quite sometime, and know that their efforts were having an impact.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: This is the last document that I'll take you to today. If we could please put up OPP00004552, page 26. Those are the scribe notes from February 13th. At 12:17... So if we can scroll down a little bit. ...Commissioner Carrique thanked you for having performed to perfection on world stage. What for you made the Windsor Operation such a success?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY
speaker: MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY

text_clean_combined: The team. Absolutely the team. It was a remarkable collaboration and cooperation. It didn't matter what uniform you were wearing, what rank you were, what role you had, it was a tremendous effort by a remarkable team.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: Is there anything else that you would like to say to the Commission that we haven't asked you this morning?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY
speaker: MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY

text_clean_combined: I don't think so at this point. Thank you.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: Those are all my questions for you, Superintendent. Thank you very much for your time.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY
speaker: MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY

text_clean_combined: Thank you.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: Okay, thank you very much. So I'd like to first call on the Government of Canada. Do you have any questions?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY
speaker: COMMISSIONER ROULEAU

text_clean_combined: Thank you, Commissioner.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. SAJEDA HEDARALY
speaker: MS. ANDREA GONSALVES

text_clean_combined: --- CROSS-EXAMINATION BY MS. ANDREA GONSALVES:
speaker: NA

text_clean_combined: Good morning, Superintendent.
speaker: MS. ANDREA GONSALVES

text_clean_combined: Good morning.
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: My name is Andrea Gonsalves, and I am one of the lawyers representing the Government of Canada in this Inquiry. I just want to begin by going back to the information you received, I guess it was late, you had many late nights, so late night on February 9th as to the state of play in Windsor when you were assigned the role of Critical Incident Commander. And in response to questions from Commission Counsel, you'll recall that he pulled up the bullet point email that you sent to the two deputies.
speaker: MS. ANDREA GONSALVES

text_clean_combined: Yes.
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: And one of the concerns that was raised with you early on, I gather, was the dynamics of the crowd that was engaged in the protest activity; right?
speaker: MS. ANDREA GONSALVES

text_clean_combined: Yes.
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: Under your direction, PLT teams became engaged early on trying to identify leaders; right?
speaker: MS. ANDREA GONSALVES

text_clean_combined: Yes.
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: But as you understood from the PLT teams, the protesters were disjointed, disorganised I think were your words; right?
speaker: MS. ANDREA GONSALVES

text_clean_combined: Yes; correct.
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: And in this kind of a situation, police don't know whether the group will even listen to someone who puts themselves forward as a leader; right?
speaker: MS. ANDREA GONSALVES

text_clean_combined: That's correct, and especially in this instance because we -- nobody was really being identified as a leader.
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: Right. And there was -- I understand you spoke about the three groups, there was some infighting among them?
speaker: MS. ANDREA GONSALVES

text_clean_combined: Yes.
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: And the demands of the group, to the extent they were even known, were problematic.
speaker: MS. ANDREA GONSALVES

text_clean_combined: Yes.
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: Right? I think I saw in your notes of February 10th at OPP00004543 that the protesters had no desire to leave and wanted to remain until all restrictions were lifted. That was your understanding?
speaker: MS. ANDREA GONSALVES

text_clean_combined: Yes.
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: Your bullet point note to the Deputy Chiefs also talked about the crowd being agitated, and that was true at various times through the protest; right?
speaker: MS. ANDREA GONSALVES

text_clean_combined: That's correct.
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: In your notes again February 10th, I saw that you described a wilder crowd arriving at night?
speaker: MS. ANDREA GONSALVES

text_clean_combined: Yes.
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: That's when the drinking and the pot smoking would begin?
speaker: MS. ANDREA GONSALVES

text_clean_combined: Yes.
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: Yes. And Inspector Younan described the crowd dynamics as being violent; do you remember that?
speaker: MS. ANDREA GONSALVES

text_clean_combined: Yes.
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: We heard evidence from Deputy Chief Crowley yesterday, but I just want to confirm, you were also aware from the briefings you received that there had been threats to surround and storm police station?
speaker: MS. ANDREA GONSALVES

text_clean_combined: Yes, as well as the tunnel.
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: The tunnel? Right. Officers were swarmed when they tried to arrest the individual whose car jumped the curb?
speaker: MS. ANDREA GONSALVES

text_clean_combined: That's correct.
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: There had been threats when attempts were made to tow two vehicles prior to your arrival?
speaker: MS. ANDREA GONSALVES

text_clean_combined: Yes.
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: You heard about a possible protest at the Windsor Airport?
speaker: MS. ANDREA GONSALVES

text_clean_combined: That I did not.
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: Okay.
speaker: MS. ANDREA GONSALVES

text_clean_combined: No.
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: You heard about a smoke bomb that was set off by demonstrators at one point?
speaker: MS. ANDREA GONSALVES

text_clean_combined: Yes.
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: And a bit later on in the piece, but there was a bomb threat called in about a bomb that was behind the police lines; is that correct?
speaker: MS. ANDREA GONSALVES

text_clean_combined: That is correct.
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: There had also been threats made to the mayor, his address was posted online. You knew about that?
speaker: MS. ANDREA GONSALVES

text_clean_combined: Yes, I was aware.
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: And this was all, you would accurately say -- or you'd say this was accurately described as a volatile situation?
speaker: MS. ANDREA GONSALVES

text_clean_combined: Yes.
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: There -- then you throw into the mix the presence of children; right?
speaker: MS. ANDREA GONSALVES

text_clean_combined: Correct.
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: One of your biggest concerns throughout the piece?
speaker: MS. ANDREA GONSALVES

text_clean_combined: Yes.
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: And I take it that the concern about the presence of children was based on what officers were seeing actually happening on the ground at the protest site; right?
speaker: MS. ANDREA GONSALVES

text_clean_combined: That's correct.
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: Not just information being collected online?
speaker: MS. ANDREA GONSALVES

speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: You were witnessing it. Yesterday, in questions to Deputy Chief Crowley, one of the counsel for one of the parties pulled up a situation report that was dated 0400 hours that indicated no children were observed on scene. That was 0400 hours on February 12th. Can you explain how that reconciles, if it does, with the information you received of children on site?
speaker: MS. ANDREA GONSALVES

text_clean_combined: It was always very apparent the children on site were at certain times in the day and that they were not staying overnight. So the information at 0400, the children were not present did not surprise me because information before revealed that the children were going home at night and not returning until sometimes 9, 10 a.m.
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: Okay. You also spoke -- you testified in response to questions from Commission Counsel about the increased risk of counter protests.
speaker: MS. ANDREA GONSALVES

text_clean_combined: Yes, right.
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: And the president of the autoworkers' association, who, understandably, they were quite upset by the ongoing blockade of the bridge. Do you recall the words that he used when he indicated that they wanted to come and counter protest?
speaker: MS. ANDREA GONSALVES

text_clean_combined: I believe, and I think it was recorded in my notes ---
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: M'hm.
speaker: MS. ANDREA GONSALVES

text_clean_combined: --- something indicating that they were going to knock heads or use a vehicle to push people into the river.
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: Yeah. That was on February 11th. OPP00004550, page 21. He said that they intend, "...to come on Monday with 1,000 people to crack heads or bring heavy equipment [and] push them in the river" That's pretty concerning as the Critical Incident Commander; correct?
speaker: MS. ANDREA GONSALVES

text_clean_combined: Yes.
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: And as time wore on, local residents are becoming more vocal in their opposition to the protest. I understand you were briefed at one point on counter protesters intending to damage protest vehicles.

text_clean_combined: Yes.
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: Recall that? You spoke about the injunction that was ordered by Chief Justice Morawetz of the Ontario Superior Court on February 11th, and I understand your view is that although this was one of the tools available, it was not particularly useful.
speaker: MS. ANDREA GONSALVES

text_clean_combined: I did not see a significant change in the incident.
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: Similarly, the February 11th provincial declaration of a state of emergency, I understand from your notes that a few protesters may have left, but it also caused others to dig their heels in; right?
speaker: MS. ANDREA GONSALVES

text_clean_combined: That's correct.
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: And then the third piece that happens on February 11th is the letter from the Solicitor General to Commissioner Carrique that was distributed to protesters. And I just want to confirm, you testified in response to Commission Counsel's questions that you had been made aware of a similar letter that would be handed out to protesters in Ottawa; you recall that evidence?
speaker: MS. ANDREA GONSALVES

text_clean_combined: Yes.
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: Did you understand who that letter would be coming from?
speaker: MS. ANDREA GONSALVES

text_clean_combined: The one in Ottawa?
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: Yes
speaker: MS. ANDREA GONSALVES

text_clean_combined: No, I do not. I do not know.
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: And that's because your focus, of course ---
speaker: MS. ANDREA GONSALVES

text_clean_combined: Was Windsor.
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: --- was Windsor.
speaker: MS. ANDREA GONSALVES

text_clean_combined: Yes.
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: And that letter from the Solicitor General does ultimately get handed out to protesters at the blockade site in Windsor?
speaker: MS. ANDREA GONSALVES

text_clean_combined: Yes.

text_clean_combined: And it had no effect either. They refused to leave; right?
speaker: MS. ANDREA GONSALVES

text_clean_combined: Yes.
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: Disappointingly, but that really proved to be the end point to possible engagement. It had been tried and it had failed; right?
speaker: MS. ANDREA GONSALVES

text_clean_combined: M'hm.
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: Sorry, we just need ---
speaker: MS. ANDREA GONSALVES

text_clean_combined: Yes, sorry.
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: Thank you. And there was a lot going on across the province at the time that you were dealing with the situation in Windsor, a lot of protest activity; fair?
speaker: MS. ANDREA GONSALVES

text_clean_combined: Yes.
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: We know that the Windsor Police response involved units not only from OPP and Windsor Police, but you also spoke about London, Hamilton, Waterloo, I think?
speaker: MS. ANDREA GONSALVES

text_clean_combined: Correct.
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: Yeah. Perhaps some other municipal police services or does that cover it?

text_clean_combined: I believe that covers it.
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: And you were told that Windsor was your priority; right?
speaker: MS. ANDREA GONSALVES

text_clean_combined: Yes.
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: But you were certainly well aware that there were ongoing and expected demonstrations and blockades across the province?
speaker: MS. ANDREA GONSALVES

text_clean_combined: Right. Yes, I was aware.
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: I saw through your notes this reference to a ripple effect. Am I understanding, Superintendent, that you saw the convoys and the blockades in the various locations as being connected in the sense that they couldn't be managed or approached in isolation from a policing perspective?
speaker: MS. ANDREA GONSALVES

text_clean_combined: Certainly, all of them had to be considered. I think I'll go back to the example of the Facebook page that I mentioned and Take Back the Bridge. It was obvious that people were monitoring what police activity was, and then making plans according to that.
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: And you were aware, or certainly alive to the concern that what happened at one site could well have impacts at others?
speaker: MS. ANDREA GONSALVES

text_clean_combined: Correct.
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: Right. Now after the 11th, everything, fair to say, had been tried and the time had come for the operational plan to be implemented; right?
speaker: MS. ANDREA GONSALVES

text_clean_combined: Yes.
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: And it ultimately succeeds in fully clearing that blockade on Sunday the 13th; right?
speaker: MS. ANDREA GONSALVES

text_clean_combined: Correct.
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: The vehicles were towed. One thing I didn't hear come out in your evidence in-Chief, but I saw in your notes, OPP00004544 at page 14 that bomb threats had been made to the tow operator. That was AMPM Towing; is that right?
speaker: MS. ANDREA GONSALVES

text_clean_combined: Yes, Windsor Police Service was dealing with that because it was their jurisdiction, but I was aware that the towing company had received threats, both internally, so on their phone, and also too that a number of people had called continuously to this -- the business, and so basically, their phone service wasn't available because people kept tying up the lines. And in regards to tow trucks, when the others were staged from the States, we also received information that people were going to -- protesters were going to go and block the area where we had them staged, so that we potentially were not able to use them, so I had to assign additional officers to that area.
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: Okay. And fair for me to say that even after the operation had successfully cleared the blockade, you were deeply concerned about maintaining that road clear; right?
speaker: MS. ANDREA GONSALVES

text_clean_combined: Yes.
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: That was your single biggest concern, in fact, was maintaining the hold, somewhat precarious hold on Huron Church Road; right?
speaker: MS. ANDREA GONSALVES

text_clean_combined: Yes.
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: And I saw in your notes -- perhaps we could turn them up, OPP00004556 at page -- it's stamped page 16, but I think in the electronic document it would be page 17. Yeah, right there is good. And I see fourth line down, "Now we have to maintain it - May have groundhog day -- could be groundhog day - have to be on high alert." What did you mean by it could be Groundhog Day?
speaker: MS. ANDREA GONSALVES

text_clean_combined: They could attempt -- again, they had obviously proven to the world at this time that they were able to block it, so that they knew it was achievable.
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: And this ongoing risk that the protesters would return and resume the blockade, I take it that your concern was informed not only by what you saw in Windsor, but your experience with these ongoing slow roll protests even going back to January?
speaker: MS. ANDREA GONSALVES

text_clean_combined: Yes.
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: And as the POU operation loomed in Ottawa, you made clear that you couldn't spare resources from Windsor to assist with that; right?
speaker: MS. ANDREA GONSALVES

text_clean_combined: I made it clear that I needed a contingent of POU officers still available.
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: Right. And in fact, after the blockade was cleared on the 13th and the bridge reopened on the 14th, I understand there were threats to block the tunnel. Those threats came in very shortly after the bridge was cleared?
speaker: MS. ANDREA GONSALVES

text_clean_combined: Yes.
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: You mentioned the 15th there was a convoy of vehicles believed to have been travelling to Windsor that was intercepted?
speaker: MS. ANDREA GONSALVES

text_clean_combined: Yes.
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: On the 16th, if we could pull up OPP00000209? And scroll down, please. Just pausing there. Your -- this is an email dated February 16th and we see your name there, Superintendent?
speaker: MS. ANDREA GONSALVES

text_clean_combined: Yes.
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: Okay. Keep scrolling down. And this is an email communicating to you and others the most recent updated PLT messaging that incorporates both the federal and provincial emergency orders. You recall receiving that?
speaker: MS. ANDREA GONSALVES

text_clean_combined: I received a lot of emails, but yes.
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: But you're aware, in any event, of the needing to get out PLT messaging of the two emergency -- the levels of emergency orders; right?
speaker: MS. ANDREA GONSALVES

text_clean_combined: Yes.
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: Including what we see in the first paragraph in black, "Persons travelling to any other unlawful protest sites to participate in or support the unlawful demonstration can be charged." And that is the PLT messaging being put out to deter protesters from going to sites where blockades might be resumed or renewed; yes?
speaker: MS. ANDREA GONSALVES

text_clean_combined: Yes, and providing them the education of what could happen.
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: Right, what the consequences are.
speaker: MS. ANDREA GONSALVES

text_clean_combined: Yes.
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: Exactly. So you also mentioned the Facebook chat about protesters heading back to Ambassador Bridge as the enforcement action was taking place in Ottawa.
speaker: MS. ANDREA GONSALVES

text_clean_combined: Yes.
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: And let's just pull up OPP00004558. I've come to learn this is what we call fast facts.
speaker: MS. ANDREA GONSALVES

text_clean_combined: Yes.
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: And this is pages 92 and 93. Let's just start at 92. Scroll down, please. A little bit more. There we go. The bullet point towards the bottom of the page, private chat on Facebook by group by the name of Windsor Convoy for Freedom. "...all police are in Ottawa so let's take the bridge back."
speaker: MS. ANDREA GONSALVES

text_clean_combined: Yes.
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: That was a concern, and there's another one on the next page. I don't have to take you there. And, of course, Superintendent, you testified before about the concern of the -- presented by counter protesters, the volatility if we have these two sides colliding; right?
speaker: MS. ANDREA GONSALVES

text_clean_combined: Yes.
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: And that concern also would have arisen if yet another blockade popped up in Windsor after it had been cleared; right?
speaker: MS. ANDREA GONSALVES

text_clean_combined: Absolutely.
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: And it's because of these concerns that you planned for the gradual rather than the sort of immediate demobilization in Windsor; right?
speaker: MS. ANDREA GONSALVES

text_clean_combined: That's correct.
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: In fact, OPP POUs were not removed from Windsor until February 24th as I understand it?
speaker: MS. ANDREA GONSALVES

text_clean_combined: Yes.
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: And that's -- you understand that's after the federal government had revoked the invocation of the Emergencies Act?
speaker: MS. ANDREA GONSALVES

text_clean_combined: Yes.
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: And we saw in your response to questions from Commission Counsel the last intersection was planned to reopen on March 13th on your advice?
speaker: MS. ANDREA GONSALVES

text_clean_combined: Yes.
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: And I understand from Deputy Chief Crowley that WPS maintained a perimeter as late as March 28th? You understand that, or you said you weren't sure?
speaker: MS. ANDREA GONSALVES

text_clean_combined: Yeah, I wasn't there, but I did hear it in his testimony.
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: And given all of the concerns and the economic impact of that bridge being closed down, not only in Windsor but in the entire region, you understood that it would be appropriately prudent and cautious to keep these measures in place long after it had been cleared; correct?
speaker: MS. ANDREA GONSALVES

text_clean_combined: Again, it was another tool that we could refer to if we had issues.
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: Because when that blockade was cleared on the 13th or the 14th, you just had no idea whether it would fall into the hands of protesters again; right?
speaker: MS. ANDREA GONSALVES

text_clean_combined: Exactly.
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: Thank you. Those are my questions.
speaker: MS. ANDREA GONSALVES

text_clean_combined: Thank you.

So if we look at this document now, the Premier and the Prime Minister are saying hello. And in the first big paragraph, Premier Ford says, "The bigger one for us and the country is the ambassador bridge and the state ground there. What I think is we gotta stop the spread of these protests..." And he goes on to say that the Attorney General is looking at legal ways to give he police more tools. Do you see that?

text_clean_combined: Yes.
speaker: SUPT. DANA EARLEY

text_clean_combined: Okay. And in the next paragraph, if we can just scroll down a little bit, the Prime Minister says, "First of all, they're not a legal protest. speaker: MR. TOM CURRY

text_clean_combined: Yes.

speaker: MS. ALLISON McMAHON

section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. ALLISON McMAHON

section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. ALLISON McMAHON
speaker: MR. PAUL LESCHIED

section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. ALLISON McMAHON
speaker: MS. ALLISON McMAHON

section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. ALLISON McMAHON
speaker: MR. PAUL LESCHIED

text_clean_combined: Okay. And have you been a life-long resident of the Essex County area?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. ALLISON McMAHON
speaker: MS. ALLISON McMAHON

text_clean_combined: I've lived in Essex County area for the better part of the last 44 years, other than the time I spent at university and briefly in Alberta for a -- as a commercial helicopter pilot.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. ALLISON McMAHON
speaker: MR. PAUL LESCHIED

text_clean_combined: And can you please tell the Commissioner about how you became involved with protests against COVID-19 public health mandates?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. ALLISON McMAHON
speaker: MS. ALLISON McMAHON

text_clean_combined: I would just say, like many other Canadians, I'd grown a little wary with the -- I guess the direction of our basic fundamental rights and freedoms kind of being transformed into privileges that can be granted or revoked based upon our personal compliance with whatever the latest mandate or bylaw that's being passed down by our federal, provincial or municipal leaders. That led me to be a little concerned as a father of three young children, the direction that this country's heading in, and so I participated in several peaceful, lawful protests, so that people's voices could be heard with these same concerns.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. ALLISON McMAHON
speaker: MR. PAUL LESCHIED

text_clean_combined: And can you tell us about those protests?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. ALLISON McMAHON
speaker: MS. ALLISON McMAHON

text_clean_combined: I mean, we had various fundraisers for people that have been negatively impacted, or had job losses, or had their businesses somewhat run into the ground, or not being able to make ends meet. We've had various freedom rallies at the flag, I guess that you would call it, at the downtown Windsor area of Riverside and Ouellette Avenue.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. ALLISON McMAHON
speaker: MR. PAUL LESCHIED

text_clean_combined: And are those the sort of weekly rallies that would take place starting in September ---
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. ALLISON McMAHON
speaker: MS. ALLISON McMAHON

text_clean_combined: I wouldn't say I was there for the weekly rallies. There have been weekly rallies and I was -- I did my part to offer whatever assistance or support that I could at several of these events over the last couple years.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. ALLISON McMAHON
speaker: MR. PAUL LESCHIED

text_clean_combined: Okay. And how would you typically hear about protests that you would attend or fundraisers or rallies?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. ALLISON McMAHON
speaker: MS. ALLISON McMAHON

text_clean_combined: I mean, I just I've made a lot of friends and that would attend some of these rallies in the area that have similar concerns that I do. So, you know, through text message, periodic meetups where people might be discussing what they would like to do or what action maybe they would like to take next.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. ALLISON McMAHON
speaker: MR. PAUL LESCHIED

speaker: MR. PAUL LESCHIED

speaker: MR. PAUL LESCHIED

section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. ALLISON McMAHON

section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. ALLISON McMAHON
speaker: MR. PAUL LESCHIED

text_clean_combined: Both.

speaker: MS. ALLISON McMAHON

speaker: MR. PAUL LESCHIED

speaker: MS. ALLISON McMAHON

speaker: MR. PAUL LESCHIED

speaker: MS. ALLISON McMAHON

speaker: MR. PAUL LESCHIED

speaker: MR. PAUL LESCHIED

section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. ALLISON McMAHON
speaker: MS. ALLISON McMAHON

text_clean_combined: Yes.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. ALLISON McMAHON
speaker: MR. PAUL LESCHIED

text_clean_combined: --- truck drivers?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. ALLISON McMAHON
speaker: MS. ALLISON McMAHON

text_clean_combined: Exactly.

speaker: MR. PAUL LESCHIED

speaker: MS. ALLISON McMAHON

speaker: MR. PAUL LESCHIED

speaker: MS. ALLISON McMAHON

section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. ALLISON McMAHON
speaker: MR. PAUL LESCHIED

section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. ALLISON McMAHON

speaker: MR. PAUL LESCHIED

section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. ALLISON McMAHON
speaker: MS. ALLISON McMAHON

text_clean_combined: I mean, the previous night, I wouldn’t suggest that there was -- I didn’t remember seeing barricades. I would say that there was police cruisers at intersections, and I guess if that represents a barricade, that would be what I would say on night number one. And then night number two, they would have some of those construction, like, orange construction wooden barricades at some of the intersections in the area.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. ALLISON McMAHON
speaker: MR. PAUL LESCHIED

text_clean_combined: Okay. And I understand from your interview summary that some protestor vehicles were able to come and go from the protest area?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. ALLISON McMAHON
speaker: MS. ALLISON McMAHON

text_clean_combined: On that second night, yes.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. ALLISON McMAHON
speaker: MR. PAUL LESCHIED

text_clean_combined: Okay. And how did that work, if there were the wooden barriers and cruisers stationed along the intersections?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. ALLISON McMAHON
speaker: MS. ALLISON McMAHON

text_clean_combined: So I remember noticing around -- between somewhere around midnight and maybe 12:30, a couple trucks that -- semi trucks or large size trucks had entered -- or had had to go around the Tecumseh Road/Huron Church intersection to go down some of the residential streets that would be west of Huron Church. And you could hear the horns. And they entered, I believe, at College Avenue and Huron Church, where there would have been a police cruiser and orange barricades. And upon them arriving at the intersection, I saw the police officers get out of the vehicles, remove the barricades, and allow the trucks to enter into that intersection, and then basically direct them to park on the southbound lanes of Huron Church Avenue south of College Avenue.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. ALLISON McMAHON
speaker: MR. PAUL LESCHIED

text_clean_combined: And did you see any other cooperation between the police and protestors?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. ALLISON McMAHON
speaker: MS. ALLISON McMAHON

I know there’s a couple intersections there that would allow you to exit to the west of Huron Church, and perhaps they were being -- the cruisers maybe would have allowed some of those trucks or passenger vehicles to exit at that point. I don’t remember actually witnessing how they were getting out.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. ALLISON McMAHON
speaker: MR. PAUL LESCHIED

speaker: MS. ALLISON McMAHON

The unlawful act of blocking streets at and near the Ambassador Bridge is resulting in people being denied the lawful use, enjoyment and operation of their property and causing businesses to close down. We are providing notice that anyone blocking streets or assisting others in the blocking of streets may be committing a criminal offence and must immediately cease further unlawful activity or you may face charges. You could be arrested if you are a party to the offence or assisting others in the direct or indirect commission of this offence.” Is this something that you saw while you were at the protests?

section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. ALLISON McMAHON
speaker: MS. ALLISON McMAHON

text_clean_combined: I would say that there was a lot of, perhaps, exaggeration of what was happening at the demonstration in Windsor. It was certainly being painted as something that I didn’t witness for the five days that I was there, which was simply a peaceful protest of people that wanted to have their voices heard.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. ALLISON McMAHON
speaker: MR. PAUL LESCHIED

speaker: MS. ALLISON McMAHON

There was only, like, four to six semi trucks that were involved in impeding or blockading traffic on that southbound Huron Church area, and it certainly made -- the coverage certainly seemed to make it sound like it was much larger in scale and scope than that.

text_clean_combined: No. It was a leaderless movement that I didn’t see one focal point that was being discussed, discussing things with law enforcement on a routine basis.

speaker: MR. PAUL LESCHIED

text_clean_combined: And did you have a sense that the protest would have ended at some point if the police hadn’t intervened, or was it the police intervention that brought it to an end?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. ALLISON McMAHON
speaker: MS. ALLISON McMAHON

text_clean_combined: I can only speculate. I mean, the police brought it to an end. How things would have unfolded if that didn’t happen, I don't know.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. ALLISON McMAHON
speaker: MR. PAUL LESCHIED

text_clean_combined: But at that point on Friday when you left, there was no sort of sense that everyone was going to start packing up and leaving?

speaker: MS. ALLISON McMAHON

speaker: MR. PAUL LESCHIED

section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. ALLISON McMAHON
speaker: MS. ALLISON McMAHON

text_clean_combined: I wouldn't say that would -- I guess that would be an assumption that I made, that you know, they wanted to have their voices heard because they had largely been silenced and they had no other -- they probably felt they had no other option as to who could they talk to regarding the mandates that were coming that would force them or cause them to be able to lose their ability to do their jobs crossing the international border.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. ALLISON McMAHON
speaker: MR. PAUL LESCHIED

text_clean_combined: And so -- and I know that this is something that you had mentioned in your interview summary as well, is that you felt like politicians were refusing to kind of engage with the protesters and hear them out; is that true?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. ALLISON McMAHON
speaker: MS. ALLISON McMAHON

section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. ALLISON McMAHON
speaker: MR. PAUL LESCHIED

section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. ALLISON McMAHON
speaker: MS. ALLISON McMAHON

text_clean_combined: No, I wouldn't say that I went there with any goals.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MS. ALLISON McMAHON
speaker: MR. PAUL LESCHIED

text_clean_combined: Okay. Could we please pull up ONT00000858? This -- if you could scroll down a bit -- keep going a little bit more -- thank you. This is a letter from the solicitor general of Ontario, Sylvia Jones, to the commissioner of the Ontario Provincial Police, which is dated February 11th. And it states: "This letter is being sent regarding the protest activity occurring in Windsor and restricting access to the Ambassador Bridge, which must end. The Government of Ontario is proposing that a meeting occur within an agreeable time period between a select group of protest leadership and representatives of the province to allow their issues to be heard. To move forward with our offer to schedule a meeting, all protesters must leave the protest site immediately, denounce all unlawful activity, and encourage a period of quiet. This means no unlawful, unpeaceful, unsafe protest activity to occur between the time of acceptance of this offer until the meeting takes place." Have you ever seen this letter before?

text_clean_combined: Correct. Yeah, it would be -- it would be shared around the various social media platforms.
speaker: MR. PAUL LESCHIED

text_clean_combined: Okay. And is that the same way that the protest on, I believe it was, September 18th, 2021, there were about 1,000 silent first responders? Was that the same type of deal? Was it promoted the same way?
speaker: MS. LANI ROUILLARD

text_clean_combined: Yeah. Yeah, I would say it was promoted on social media. It was at the same place. And there -- there would likely be 1,000 or so other protestors or gatherers to support the silent protest that the EMS and Windsor fire department were conducting.
speaker: MR. PAUL LESCHIED

text_clean_combined: So if I was not from Windsor and I was just taking a walk that day touring the town, if I went by, say, the Chris Sky protest or I went past the 1,000 protestors for the first responders, would I pick up what it was about?
speaker: MS. LANI ROUILLARD

text_clean_combined: If you -- if you stuck around, I guess, to listen to the various speakers that would be giving their -- giving their speeches those particular days.
speaker: MR. PAUL LESCHIED

text_clean_combined: Okay. So do you believe that the Mayor was aware that these speeches were going on when Chris Sky was in town or when the 1,000 protestors came out to support the first responders?
speaker: MS. LANI ROUILLARD

speaker: COMMISSIONER ROULEAU

text_clean_combined: Yeah, I’m looking -- sorry.
speaker: MS. LANI ROUILLARD

text_clean_combined: If I could be helped to understand how this is going to help the Commission.

speaker: MS. LANI ROUILLARD

speaker: COMMISSIONER ROULEAU

speaker: MS. LANI ROUILLARD

speaker: MR. PAUL LESCHIED

text_clean_combined: Okay. And did the protestors ever each out, to your knowledge, to the Mayor to communicate and say this is why we’re unhappy?
speaker: MS. LANI ROUILLARD

speaker: MR. PAUL LESCHIED

speaker: MS. LANI ROUILLARD

text_clean_combined: Okay. Are you giving evidence about what the municipal ---
speaker: COMMISSIONER ROULEAU

text_clean_combined: No.
speaker: MS. LANI ROUILLARD

text_clean_combined: I mean, I don’t know that there’s any evidence about this.
speaker: COMMISSIONER ROULEAU

text_clean_combined: No, I’m trying to understand, yeah, if the protestors had reached out to the Mayor to clearly communicate what their ambition was through the protest, if he was aware of that.
speaker: MS. LANI ROUILLARD

text_clean_combined: Yeah, and he said -- and he said he was speculating and then ---
speaker: COMMISSIONER ROULEAU

text_clean_combined: Okay.
speaker: MS. LANI ROUILLARD

text_clean_combined: --- you said something about the complaint process, which is what I was curious about. There’s -- I don’t believe there’s evidence about that.
speaker: COMMISSIONER ROULEAU

text_clean_combined: No, just to make sure the protestors acted fairly in trying to resolve the complaint first with the Mayor, with the town before they set up their protests.
speaker: MS. LANI ROUILLARD

text_clean_combined: It might help if you establish they’re the same protestors that were doing it, which may well be, but I don’t know.
speaker: COMMISSIONER ROULEAU

text_clean_combined: So the group that was participating in these protests, the three that we had discussed, there was Chris Sky, the silent responders, and then by the flag, were those all the same group? Were they just kind of growing? Was it the community of Windsor?
speaker: MS. LANI ROUILLARD

text_clean_combined: I mean, there was various groups that were -- that were helping to organize these events and bring in different speakers. Yeah, largely the same -- same people were -- were organizing or having these gatherings.
speaker: MR. PAUL LESCHIED

text_clean_combined: Okay. So I’m going to take you forward now to the night of February 7th, which is, I believe, the first night of the blockade at the Ambassador Bridge; correct?
speaker: MS. LANI ROUILLARD

text_clean_combined: Correct. Yeah.
speaker: MR. PAUL LESCHIED

text_clean_combined: Okay. So when you say that this was a group that was, you know, growing through time and there were familiar faces there, did you recognize any of the people that initially blocked the road where you were ---

text_clean_combined: No, I never ---
speaker: MR. PAUL LESCHIED

text_clean_combined: --- to the Ambassador Bridge?
speaker: MS. LANI ROUILLARD

text_clean_combined: No, I had never seen them before.

speaker: MR. PAUL LESCHIED

text_clean_combined: Okay. During the first night of the protest, did you see the police put down any jersey barriers, like the concrete barriers, or obstruct any lanes?
speaker: MS. LANI ROUILLARD

speaker: MR. PAUL LESCHIED

text_clean_combined: They definitely secured several areas around the perimeter with police vehicles. MS. LANI ROUILLARD Okay. And what would you say that the ratio was between police and protesters the first night?
speaker: MR. PAUL LESCHIED

LANI ROUILLARD So granted that, you know, according to previous counsels' questions, there were auto plant shutdowns, this is the busiest border crossing in North America, it's a vital crossing of the border, and it controls the trade for millions of dollars in our country back and forth, do you think the police were capable of shutting this down on night number one?
speaker: MR. PAUL LESCHIED

text_clean_combined: I believe if they would've have chosen, if that was their objective on night number one, certainly the few vehicles at Girardot and the dozen or so protesters that would've been there when I left, I believe they could've shut that down if that was the intention. MS. LANI ROUILLARD Okay, thank you. And when you were at the bridge, and I'm just going to speak generally about that week, the days that you were there, of course, what kind of an environment was it? How did you feel there?
speaker: MR. PAUL LESCHIED

text_clean_combined: It was just a peaceful gathering, music, food being shared. Very cordial. MS. LANI ROUILLARD And you said you weren't there during the daytime, so that's fine, but when you were there in the evening did you see any families?

speaker: MR. PAUL LESCHIED

speaker: MR. PAUL LESCHIED

speaker: MR. PAUL LESCHIED

speaker: MR. PAUL LESCHIED

text_clean_combined: I mean, it was pretty clear with the -- there was drones that were circulating overhead, and some of the law enforcement personnel there would have cameras or smartphones I guess scanning around the area to gather their own Intelligence I can imagine. text_clean_combined: So I lost access to my bank account on February 18th. MS. LANI ROUILLARD Okay, tell me about that. What happened exactly?
speaker: MR. PAUL LESCHIED

text_clean_combined: So I just -- I had gone to my bank to deposit a cheque from my business that I had written to myself, and upon trying to use the ATM I got a -- an error message or a message that it was not going to allow me access into my bank account. I tried a second ATM machine and got the same error message. I tried my online banking when I got home via my computer and continued to get messages that were not allowing me to access my own bank account. MS. LANI ROUILLARD And when did that change? How long did it last for?
speaker: MR. PAUL LESCHIED

text_clean_combined: So I was able to access my account I believe on the following Tuesday, which would be after the family day holiday weekend. MS. LANI ROUILLARD So is that a period of about five days, then?
speaker: MR. PAUL LESCHIED

text_clean_combined: About four days, give or take. MS. LANI ROUILLARD Four days? Okay. Did you ever find out why?
speaker: MR. PAUL LESCHIED

text_clean_combined: No. MS. LANI ROUILLARD Okay. Thank you. And just a follow-up question from a previous counsel. Do you need to ask permission to park at a mall in Ontario in the parking lot?
speaker: MR. PAUL LESCHIED

text_clean_combined: Not that I'm aware of. MS. LANI ROUILLARD Okay, thank you. text_clean_combined: --- STATEMENT BY MR. MARTIN REJMAN:
speaker: NA

text_clean_combined: Good afternoon, Commissioner. Martin Rejman, for the record. Mr. Van Huigenbos has recently been charged in relationship -- in relation to matters that he may be asked questions about in these proceedings, namely the events in Coutts, Alberta, that took place between January 29th and February 15th of this year, 2022. On Friday, November 4th, 2022, Mr. Van Huigenbos elected to be tried by a jury of peers. Mr. Van Huigenbos was summoned to testify this afternoon. His testimony is compelled and subject nationwide publication. Mr. Van Huigenbos invokes the protection afforded to him under the Canada Evidence Act, specifically Section 5.2, as well as the related provisions of the Alberta Evidence Act to protect his interests against any self-incrimination. He also benefits from and seeks the protection of Section 13 of the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms in his anticipated testimony. For the record, he objects to answer each and every question on the grounds that his answers may incriminate him or may/or could be used to establish any liability in the criminal or civil proceedings. He is compelled to provide answers, and we can proceed with the questions.
speaker: MR. MARTIN REJMAN

text_clean_combined: Thank you. Go ahead.
speaker: COMMISSIONER ROULEAU
